title: Big four's 'loss leader' fees threaten audit quality
text:
“If firms are using audit as a loss leader, it makes it hard for others who have the same running costs to compete.”

Winfried Bischoff, the head of the UK's Financial Reporting Council, last month told The Australian Financial Review that companies needed to pay more for quality audits.

A perception among some that only big four firms can do "complex audits" also limited competition, Mr Francis said, and extended to government agencies that often went with brand name firms because they seemed "safe".

The Bentleys submission said this was “factually incorrect” and shrunk the market “to the four firms that are perceived as being capable".

Busy season

Bentleys also told the inquiry that the time pressure auditors faced in the tight window between clients being ready for audits and regulatory deadlines cost the industry quality staff.

“We are used to the concept of a “busy season” whereby half of the year’s work needs to be compressed into a quarter of the year. However, it can be challenging to attract and retain sufficiently qualified and experienced auditors to commit to this each year,” the submission said.

“Many competent auditors tire of this constant pressure and opt for roles in commerce.”

Another submission to the inquiry, the author of which was redacted, said the stress of a busy season on overworked junior auditors meant the final steps of audits were not completed satisfactorily.

Mr Francis called for audit deadlines to be spread through the year, with different timelines based on company size or sector both possible solutions.

ASIC’s reporting

Bentleys' submission also said ASIC’s audit inspection process was up to scratch, contradicting Deloitte’s managing partner of audit and assurance Jamie Gatt's stance that ASIC’s reporting is “not fit for purpose”.

“The feedback I get from across the group is when ASIC does come and audit files, it’s a really comprehensive and detailed process. They really focus on an area and dig into it,” Mr Francis said.

He also said the corporate watchdog did “a good job” of communicating where it saw risks and stuck to these “pretty consistently”.

This counters complaints from large audit firms that they do not know how ASIC chooses its areas of focus each year, which Monash University auditing professor Robyn Moroney said was a common concern.

Mr Francis said the issue with ASIC’s reporting instead lay in the results being “sensationalised” by the media and hence misunderstood by the public.

“It’s not the audit itself that has failed or is wrong, but the sufficiency of documented audit evidence the auditors relied on when forming their opinion."

Bentleys also undergoes its own audit checks, where partners from other cities peer-review and rate each other’s audits. These results matched those of ASIC's reviews on audits that underwent both processes.

In its submission, Bentleys said it understood some firms did not have a similarly robust annual quality assurance process, suggesting this may lead to reliance on insufficient audit evidence.
description: Big four firms using audit as a ‘loss leader’ to get more lucrative consulting work from audit clients risk creating an uncompetitive audit market, according to a national accounting firm.
